choices: involves the setting of medium-term targets for broad money aggregates.
involves the manipulation by a central bank of the government’s budget deficit.
seeks to influence the macroeconomy by influencing the quantity of money and credit in the economy.
Fiscal Policy Implementation 99
explanation: C is correct, as monetary policy involves central bank activities directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit. Choice A is incorrect because, although the setting of targets for monetary aggregates is a possible tool of monetary policy, monetary policy itself is concerned with influencing the overall, or macro, economy. ( Fiscal Policy / Deficits and national debt, p.90 PDF)
stem: Which of the following statements best describes monetary policy? Monetary policy

choices: is used by governments to redistribute wealth and incomes.
is the attempt by governments to balance their budgets from one year to the next.
involves the use of government spending and taxation to influence economy activity.
Central bank actions that grow the money supply to address deflationary conditions decrease fiscal deficits.
explanation: C is correct. Note that governments may wish to use fiscal policy to redistribute income and balance their budgets, but the overriding goal of fiscal policy is usually to influence a broader range of economic activity. ( Fiscal Policy / Deficits and national debt, p.90 PDF)
stem: Which of the following statements best describes fiscal policy? Fiscal policy

choices: Temporary suspension of payroll taxes
Public spending on a high-speed railway
Freeze in discretionary government spending
United Kingdom
explanation: C is correct. A freeze in discretionary government spending is an example of a contractionary fiscal policy. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.95 PDF)
stem: Which of the following best represents a contractionary fiscal policy

choices: Neutral
Expansionary
Contractionary
they may finance investment in physical and human capital.
explanation: A is correct. A “pay-as-you-go” rule is a neutral policy because any increases in spending or reductions in revenues would be offset. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy implementation, p.95 PDF)
stem: A “pay-as-you-go” rule, which requires that any tax cut or increase in entitlement spending be offset by an increase in other taxes or reduction in other entitlement spending, is an example of which fiscal policy stance

choices: Full employment
Near full employment
Considerable unemployment
Central bank actions that grow the money supply to address deflationary conditions decrease fiscal deficits.
explanation: C is correct. When an economy is close to full employment, a fiscal expansion raising aggregate demand can have little impact on output because there are few spare unused resources (e.g., labor or idle factories); instead, there will be upward pressure on prices (i.e., inflation). ( Fiscal Policy / Deficits and national debt, p.99 PDF)
stem: Fiscal expansions will most likely have the greatest impact on aggregate output when the economy is in which of the following states

choices: They may crowd out private investment.
They may facilitate tax changes to reduce distortions in an economy.
They may stimulate employment when there is substantial unemployment in an economy.
New capital spending by the government on road building
explanation: A is correct. A frequent argument against raises in fiscal deficits is that the additional borrowing to fund the deficit in financial markets will displace private sector borrowing for investment (i.e., crowding out). ( Fiscal Policy / Deficits and national debt, p.99 PDF)
stem: Which one of the following is most likely a reason to not use fiscal deficits as an expansionary tool

choices: the debt is owed internally to fellow citizens.
they create disincentives for economic activity.
they may finance investment in physical and human capital.
Government (or national) debt
explanation: B is correct. The belief is that high levels of debt to GDP may lead to higher future tax rates, which may lead to disincentives to economic activity. ( Fiscal Policy / Deficits and national debt, p.99 PDF)
stem: The most likely argument against high national debt levels is that

choices: According to the Ricardian equivalence, deficits have a multiplicative effect on consumer spending.
Higher government spending may lead to higher interest rates and lower private sector investing.
Central bank actions that grow the money supply to address deflationary conditions decrease fiscal deficits.
They may facilitate tax changes to reduce distortions in an economy.
explanation: B is correct. Government borrowing may compete with private sector borrowing for investment purposes. ( Fiscal Policy / Deficits and national debt, p.100 PDF)
stem: Which statement regarding fiscal deficits is most accurate

choices: Excise duty
Value-added tax
Employment taxes
ensure the stability of the purchasing power of its currency.
explanation: C is correct. Both excise duty and value-added tax (VAT) are applied to prices, whereas taxes on employment apply to labor income and hence are not indirect taxes. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.92 PDF)
stem: Which of the following is not an indirect tax

choices: Direct taxes are useful for discouraging alcohol consumption.
Because indirect taxes cannot be changed quickly, they are of no use in fiscal policy.
Government capital spending decisions are slow to plan, implement, and execute and hence are of little use for short-term economic stabilization.
Fiscal Policy Tools 97
explanation: C is correct. Capital spending is much slower to implement than changes in indirect taxes; and indirect taxes affect alcohol consumption more directly than direct taxes. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.103 PDF)
stem: Which of the following statements is most accurate

choices: Discretionary fiscal changes are aimed at stabilizing an economy.
Automatic fiscal stabilizers include new plans for additional road building by the government.
In the context of implementing fiscal policy, the recognition lag is often referred to as “driving while looking in the rearview mirror.”
Regulation of the payment system
explanation: B is correct. New plans for road building are discretionary and not automatic. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy implementation, p.103 PDF)
stem: Which of the following statements is least accurate

choices: Accommodative monetary policy reduces the impact of a fiscal stimulus.
Different statistical models will predict different impacts for a fiscal stimulus.
It is always possible to precisely predict the impact of a fiscal stimulus on employment.
USD100 USD20 USD80 USD72 USD8
explanation: B is correct. Different models embrace differing views on how the economy works, including differing views on the impact of fiscal stimuli. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.109 PDF)
stem: Which of the following statements regarding a fiscal stimulus is most accurate

choices: redistribute income and wealth.
influence aggregate national output.
ensure the stability of the purchasing power of its currency.
A rise in social transfer payments
explanation: C is correct. Ensuring stable purchasing power is a goal of monetary rather than fiscal policy. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.95 PDF)
stem: The least likely goal of a government’s fiscal policy is to

choices: Rise in capital gains taxes
Cuts in personal income taxes
New capital spending by the government on road building
A rise in social transfer payments
explanation: A is correct. A rise in capital gains taxes reduces income available for spending and hence reduces aggregate demand, other things being equal. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.99 PDF)
stem: Which of the following is not associated with an expansionary fiscal policy

choices: A rise in social transfer payments
The purchase of new equipment for the armed forces
An increase in deposit requirements for the buying of houses
LEARNING OUTCOMES
explanation: C is correct. Rises in deposit requirements for house purchases are intended to reduce the demand for credit for house purchases and hence would be considered a tool of monetary policy. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.90 PDF)
stem: Which of the following is not a tool of fiscal policy

choices: Public financing of a power plant
Regulation of the payment system
Central bank’s purchase of government bonds
Accommodative monetary policy reduces the impact of a fiscal stimulus.
explanation: A is correct. Public financing of a power plant could be described as a fiscal policy tool to stimulate investment. ( Fiscal Policy / Fiscal policy tools and objectives, p.99 PDF)
stem: Which of the following is the most likely example of a tool of fiscal policy

choices: Fiscal Policy and Aggregate Demand Aggregate demand
Difficulties in Executing Fiscal Policy
United Kingdom
Fiscal Policy and Aggregate Demand

stem: Which one of the following most likely refers to:

choices: lender of last resort.
banker to the government and banks.
body that sets tax rates on interest on savings.
Ability to “import” the inflation experience of the economy whose currency is being targeted
explanation: C is correct. A central bank is normally the lender of last resort and the banker to the banks and government, but the determination of all tax rates is normally the preserve of the government and is a fiscal policy issue. ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.117 PDF)
stem: A central bank is normally not the

choices: Price stability
Fast economic growth
Current account surplus
the transmission mechanism of monetary policy is better understood.
explanation: A is correct. Central banks normally have a variety of objectives, but the overriding one is nearly always price stability. ( Monetary Policy / Transmission mechanism, p.119 PDF)
stem: Which of the following best describes the overarching, long-run objective of most central banks

choices: Lender of last resort
Supplier of the currency
Sole supervisor of banks
Monetary Policy Objectives 129
explanation: C is correct. The supervision of banks is not a role that all central banks assume. ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.114 PDF)
stem: Which role is a central bank least likely to assume

choices: Asset prices only
Expectations about future interest rates only
Both asset prices and expectations about future interest rates
effective when combating a deflationary economy.
explanation: C is correct. The price of equities, for example, might be affected by the expectation of future policy interest rate changes. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary policy tools, p.123 PDF)
stem: Which of the following variables are most likely to be affected by a change in a central bank’s policy rate

choices: Import prices
Domestic inflation
Inflation expectations
banker to the government and banks.
explanation: C is correct. By setting its official interest rate, a central bank could expect to have a direct influence on inflation expectations—as well as on other market interest rates, asset prices, and the exchange rate (where this is freely floating). ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.123 PDF)
stem: Which of the following does a central bank seek to influence directly via the setting of its official interest rate

choices: setting an inflation rate target.
changing an official interest rate.
enacting a transfer payment program.
Domestic Demand
explanation: C is correct. Transfer payment programs represent fiscal, not monetary policy. ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.119 PDF)
stem: Monetary policy is least likely to include

choices: Central bank activities are typically intended to maintain price stability.
Monetary policies work through the economy via four independent channels.
Commercial and interbank interest rates move inversely to official interest rates.
Domestic Demand
explanation: A is correct. Central bank activities are typically intended to maintain price stability. ( Monetary Policy / Transmission mechanism, p.123 PDF)
stem: Which is the most accurate statement regarding central banks and monetary policy

choices: they are the lender of last resort.
they set targets that can become self-fulfilling prophecies.
they are the monopolistic suppliers of the currency.
Targeting zero percent inflation runs a higher risk of a deflationary outcome.
explanation: B is correct. If a central bank operates within an inflation-targeting regime and if economic agents believe that it will achieve its target, this expectation will become embedded into wage negotiations, for example, and become a self-fulfilling prophecy. ( Monetary Policy / Central bank independence, p.125 PDF)
stem: The degree of credibility that a central bank is afforded by economic agents is important because

choices: target independent and operationally independent.
target independent but not operationally independent.
operationally independent but not target independent.
Quantitative Easing and Policy Interaction
explanation: A is correct. The central bank described is target independent because it set its own targets (e.g., the target inflation rate) and operationally independent because it decides how to achieve its targets (e.g., the time horizon). ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.130 PDF)
stem: A central bank that decides the desired levels of interest rates and inflation and the horizon over which the inflation objective is to be achieved is most accurately described as being

choices: Freedom to pursue redistributive fiscal policy
Freedom to set interest rates according to domestic conditions
Ability to “import” the inflation experience of the economy whose currency is being targeted
Sole supervisor of banks
explanation: C is correct. Note that interest rates have to be set to achieve this target and are therefore subordinate to the exchange rate target and partially dependent on economic conditions in the foreign economy. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary–fiscal interaction, p.115 PDF)
stem: With regard to monetary policy, what is the expected benefit of adopting an exchange rate target

choices: Fiscal deficits
Rapid financial innovation
Absence of a liquid government bond market
the government sector would tend to expand as a proportion of total GDP.
explanation: A is correct. Note that the absence of a liquid government bond market through which a central bank can enact open market operations and/or repo transactions will inhibit the implementation of monetary policy—as would rapid financial innovation because such innovation can change the relationship between money and economic activity. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary–fiscal interaction, p.119 PDF)
stem: Which of the following is least likely to be an impediment to the successful implementation of monetary policy in developing economies

choices: Increase in short-term interest rates
Increase in the domestic money supply
Increase in its foreign currency reserves
Inflation Rate
explanation: A is correct. Interest rates are expected to rise to protect the exchange rate target. ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.133 PDF)
stem: A country that maintains a target exchange rate is most likely to have which outcome when its inflation rate rises above the level of the inflation rate in the target country

choices: reducing consumer demand.
reducing the foreign exchange value of the currency.
driving up asset prices leading to an increase in personal sector wealth.
Country Institutions
explanation: A is correct. If an increase in the central bank’s policy rate is successfully transmitted through the money markets to other parts of the financial sector, consumer demand might decline as the rate of interest on mortgages and other credit rises. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary policy tools, p.120 PDF)
stem: An increase in a central bank’s policy rate might be expected to reduce inflationary pressures by

choices: cannot control the inflation rate perfectly.
are appointed by politicians and are therefore never truly independent.
cannot control the amount of money that economic agents put in banks, nor the willingness of banks to make loans.
Japan Financial Services Agency
explanation: C is correct. Central bankers do not control the decisions of individuals and banks that can influence the money creation process. ( Monetary Policy / Limitations of monetary policy, p.128 PDF)
stem: Which of the following statements best describes a fundamental limitation of monetary policy? Monetary policy is limited because central bankers

choices: stable inflation.
balanced budgets.
greater employment.
Freedom to set interest rates according to domestic conditions
explanation: A is correct. The neutral rate of interest is that rate of interest that neither stimulates nor slows down the underlying economy. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary policy tools, p.139 PDF)
stem: In theory, setting the policy rate equal to the neutral interest rate should promote

choices: real interest rates have a more powerful effect on the real economy.
the transmission mechanism of monetary policy is better understood.
the future impact of fiscal policy changes are fully discounted by economic agents.
Monetary Policy Objectives 121
explanation: C is correct. If Ricardian equivalence holds, then economic agents anticipate that the consequence of any current tax cut will be future tax rises, which leads them to increase their saving in anticipation of this so that the tax cut has little effect on consumption and investment decisions. ( Monetary Policy / Transmission mechanism, p.143 PDF)
stem: In a world in which Ricardian equivalence holds, governments would most likely prefer to use monetary rather than fiscal policy because under Ricardian equivalence

choices: interest rates would tend to fall, reinforcing the fiscal policy stance.
the government sector would tend to shrink as a proportion of total GDP.
the government sector would tend to expand as a proportion of total GDP.
effective when a specific group is targeted.
explanation: C is correct. With a tight monetary policy, real interest rates should rise and reduce private sector activity, which could be at least partially offset by an expansion in government activity via the loosening of fiscal policy. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary–fiscal interaction, p.140 PDF)
stem: If fiscal policy is easy and monetary policy tight, then

choices: government spending
rise in transfer benefits
cut in labor income tax across all income levels
reducing the foreign exchange value of the currency.
explanation: A is correct. The study clearly showed that direct spending by the government leads to a larger impact on GDP than changes in taxes or benefits. ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.143 PDF)
stem: Which of the following has the greatest impact on aggregate demand according to an IMF study? 1 percent of GDP stimulus in

choices: implementable quickly.
effective when a specific group is targeted.
effective when combating a deflationary economy.
real interest rates have a more powerful effect on the real economy.
explanation: A is correct. Monetary actions may face fewer delays to taking action than fiscal policy, especially when the central bank is independent. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary–fiscal interaction, p.124 PDF)
stem: Given an independent central bank, monetary policy actions are more likely than fiscal policy actions to be

choices: Easy fiscal/easy monetary policy
Easy fiscal/tight monetary policy
Tight fiscal/tight monetary policy
Rapid financial innovation
explanation: A is correct. If both fiscal and monetary policies are “easy,” then the joint impact will be highly expansionary, leading to a rise in aggregate demand, low interest rates, and growing private and public sectors. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary–fiscal interaction, p.144 PDF)
stem: Which policy alternative is most likely to be effective for growing both the public and private sectors

choices: Some inflation is viewed as being good for an economy.
It is very difficult to eliminate all inflation from a modern economy.
Targeting zero percent inflation runs a higher risk of a deflationary outcome.
Absence of a liquid government bond market
explanation: C is correct. Inflation targeting is art, not science. ( Monetary Policy / Inflation targeting, p.127 PDF)
stem: The reason some inflation-targeting banks may target low inflation and not zero percent inflation is best described by which of the following statements

choices: it must also target domestic inflation.
it must also set targets for broad money growth.
conditions in the domestic economy must adapt to accommodate this target.
Monetary Policy Objectives 123
explanation: C is correct. The adoption of an exchange rate target requires that the central bank set interest rates to achieve this target. ( Monetary Policy / Central bank objectives, p.131 PDF)
stem: When the central bank chooses to target a specific value for its exchange rate

choices: 4 percent
5 percent
6 percent

explanation: A is correct. The neutral rate of interest, which in this example is 5 percent, is considered to be that rate of interest that neither spurs on nor slows down the underlying economy. ( Monetary Policy / Monetary policy tools, p.128 PDF)
